title: R44526
content: The report provides an overview of FY2017 judiciary appropriations, detailing major actions such as budget submissions, hearings, markups, and the enactment of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017. The Budget for Fiscal Year 2017 requested $7.58 billion in new budget. The report outlines the FY2017 judiciary budget request of $7.58 billion, including discretionary and mandatory funds for judges' salaries. The House Appropriations Committee recommended $7.55 billion in funds for the judiciary branch activities. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees recommended $7.55 billion and $7.58 billion, respectively, in funds for the judiciary branch activities in the FY2017 Financial Services and General Government bill. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $7.58 billion in funds for the judiciary in the FY2017 FSGG bill, including mandatory funds for judges' salaries and benefits. The House agreed to a structured rule for consideration of the bill, with one amendment related to reducing funding for the Salaries and Expenses Account by $1 million. The amendment reduced funding to the Salaries and Expenses Account by $1 million. It was passed on July 7 as part of an en bloc amendment. H.R. 5485, as amended, was agreed to with a vote of 239-185. No further action was taken on the bill before the start of FY2017. Judicial branch activities were funded through continuing appropriations resolutions until the enactment of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017. This act provided $7.5 billion for the judiciary, an increase of $176.2 million from FY2016. The judiciary funding for FY2016 was $7.344 billion, an increase of $73.9 million from FY2015. This amount was $184.1 million less than the judiciary's request. In FY2015, funding was $7.261 billion, an increase of $221.9 million from FY2014, but $37.9 million less than the request. There was a funding gap in FY2014 due to the lack of enacted appropriations bills. In FY2014, a funding gap led to a partial government shutdown for 16 days until a CR (P.L. 113-46) was enacted on October 17, 2013. This CR provided funding through January 15, 2014. A consolidated appropriations bill (P.L. 113-76) was then enacted on January 17, 2014, allocating $7.039 billion for the judiciary, which makes up about 0.2% of the total budget authority. The Supreme Court's funding, including salaries, expenses, and building maintenance, accounts for approximately 1% of the judiciary's budget. The judiciary's budget includes funding for lower federal courts and related services. The largest account covers salaries and expenses for U.S. Courts of Appeals, District Courts, and other judicial services. Defender Services and Court Security are also funded. The judiciary budget includes funding for various court services, with the largest accounts allocated to Defender Services and Court Security. Other portions of the budget go towards specific courts and administrative offices within the federal court system. The judiciary uses non-appropriated funds, mainly from court filing fees, to offset expenses in various court services accounts. These funds are considered "unencumbered" and can be carried forward from year to year, resulting from savings in areas where budgeted costs did not materialize. The judiciary's financial plan includes savings in areas where budgeted costs did not materialize, with no control over certain expenses like judgeships, rent, and technology funding. The budget request and appropriations figures reflect net resources and do not include non-appropriated funds. Encumbered funds are used for delayed expenses, focusing on cost containment efforts in office space rental, personnel expenses, and technology needs. The judiciary continues cost-containment efforts, focusing on office space rental, personnel expenses, information technology, and operating costs. Judge Julia S. Gibbons emphasizes ongoing initiatives to reduce cost growth, including shared administrative services and reducing space footprint. The judiciary is reevaluating cost savings accounting practices and has achieved a $1.5 billion cost reduction over 10 years. Efforts to reduce total space by 3% have resulted in $5.8 million in rent savings. Judicial security improvements have been prompted by recent safety concerns. Efforts to improve judicial security have been spurred by recent safety concerns, including high-profile incidents such as the double homicide of a federal judge's family members in Chicago in 2005 and the sniper shooting of a state judge in Reno in 2006. The Court Security Improvement Act of 2007 aimed to enhance security for judges, court personnel, and the public, with measures such as intrusion detection systems for judges' homes and collaboration with the U.S. Marshals Service. The judiciary has been working closely with the U.S. Marshals Service to ensure courtroom safety. A pilot program was initiated in FY2009 for USMS to handle perimeter security at selected courthouses previously managed by FPS. USMS took over security functions at seven courthouses in various locations. The program is being evaluated for improvements, with the judiciary reimbursing USMS for protective measures. The judiciary and USMS are evaluating a program for courtroom safety in Baton Rouge. The Judicial Conference recommended creating 57 new federal judgeships, but no action has been taken on the bills introduced. Requests for new judgeships have been made in previous Congresses, but no final action was taken. Since 1990, the Judicial Conference has been monitoring judgeship legislation. Since 1990, the number of appellate judgeships has remained at 179 despite a 40% increase in appellate court case filings. In contrast, the number of district judgeships increased by 5% to 677 while district court case filings rose by 38%.
